articles.headline: Medicaid Cut Places States in Budget Bind
articles.snippet: At least 30 states will have to close shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.
articles.abstract: At least 30 states will have to close shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Having counted on Washington for money that may not be delivered, at least 30 states will have to close larger-than-anticipated shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.

articles.headline: Military Taps Social Networking Skills
articles.snippet: Young Air Force analysts are showing how the Facebook generation’s skills are being exploited — and paying dividends — in America’s wars.
articles.abstract: Young Air Force analysts are showing how the Facebook generation’s skills are being exploited — and paying dividends — in America’s wars.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEALE AIR FORCE BASE, Calif.  As a teenager, Jamie Christopher would tap instant messages to make plans with friends, and later she became a Facebook regular.

articles.headline: Imagining the Worst in BP’s Future
articles.snippet: With BP shares plunging since the oil rig accident, many are speculating about the company’s options.
articles.abstract: With BP shares plunging since the oil rig accident, many are speculating about the company’s options.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems unthinkable, even now, that the disastrous oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico could bring down the mighty BP. But investment bankers get paid to think the unthinkable — and that is just what they are doing.

articles.headline: Army Leak Suspect Is Turned In, by Ex-Hacker
articles.snippet: A former hacker turned in an Army intelligence analyst who claimed he gave Wikileaks video of a U.S. airstrike in Afghanistan that killed 97 civilians last year.
articles.abstract: A former hacker turned in an Army intelligence analyst who claimed he gave Wikileaks video of a U.S. airstrike in Afghanistan that killed 97 civilians last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It was only last month that a 22-year-old Army intelligence analyst in Iraq, Specialist Bradley Manning, reached out to a former computer hacker who apparently seemed like a kindred soul.

articles.headline: As China’s Wages Rise, Export Prices Could Follow
articles.snippet: Salary increases are expected to affect many stages of the supply chain, forcing companies to raise prices and possibly shift to higher-end goods.
articles.abstract: Salary increases are expected to affect many stages of the supply chain, forcing companies to raise prices and possibly shift to higher-end goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  The cost of doing business in China is going up.

articles.headline: Rate of Oil Leak, Still Not Clear, Puts Doubt on BP
articles.snippet: With no consensus on how much oil is leaking, it is hard to assess the containment cap’s effectiveness.
articles.abstract: With no consensus on how much oil is leaking, it is hard to assess the containment cap’s effectiveness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Staring day after day at images of oil billowing from an undersea well in the Gulf of Mexico, many Americans are struggling to make sense of the numbers.
articles.byline: By Justin Gillis and Henry Fountain

articles.headline: Web of Shell Companies Veils Trade by Iran’s Ships
articles.snippet: A New York Times examination shows how Iran has used a succession of stratagems, including changing ships’ names and owners, to stay one step ahead of sanctions.
articles.abstract: A New York Times examination shows how Iran has used a succession of stratagems, including changing ships’ names and owners, to stay one step ahead of sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Jan. 24, 2009, a rusting freighter flying a Hong Kong flag dropped anchor in the South African port of Durban. The stop was not on the ship’s customary route, and it stayed only an hour, just long enough to pick up its clandestine cargo: a Bladerunner 51 speedboat that could be armed with torpedoes and used as a fast-attack craft in the Persian Gulf.

articles.headline: Off Runway, Brazilian Beauty Goes Beyond Blond
articles.snippet: While images of beauty are changing in Brazil, fashion scouts are mostly searching for another Gisele Bündchen.
articles.abstract: While images of beauty are changing in Brazil, fashion scouts are mostly searching for another Gisele Bündchen.
articles.lead_paragraph: RESTINGA SÊCA, Brazil — Before setting out in a pink S.U.V. to comb the schoolyards and shopping malls of southern Brazil, Alisson Chornak studies books, maps and Web sites to understand how the towns were colonized and how European their residents might look today.

articles.headline: Lincoln Bucks Tide; Business Leaders Win in California
articles.snippet: Senator Blanche Lincoln survived in Arkansas, and Carly Fiorina and Meg Whitman won in California on a night that suggested the unpredictability of the election season.
articles.abstract: Senator Blanche Lincoln survived in Arkansas, and Carly Fiorina and Meg Whitman won in California on a night that suggested the unpredictability of the election season.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Senator Blanche Lincoln of Arkansas survived a tough challenge from her party’s left wing on Tuesday to capture the Democratic nomination in a runoff primary election, resisting the anti-incumbent wave that has defined the midterm election year.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney
